dc:description: TMEM132E was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive nonsyndromic hearing loss (ARNSHL) in 2003 (Cheng et al., 12673573). The proposed disease mechanism is loss of function. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data. Three variants (all missense) have been reported in two probands in two publications (PMIDs: 25331638, 31656313) for a genetic evidence score of 1.75 points. Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 2 additional family members (PMID: 31656313). This gene-disease association is supported by animal models and an expression study (PMIDs: 25331638, 31656313) detailing expression of TMEM132E in the mouse cochlea, phenocopied ARNHL in Zebrafish, and wild type rescue of the phenotype seen in Zebrafish whereas the variant seen in the proband (PMID: 25331638) did not. This resulted in an experimental evidence score of 3.5 points. In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the Hearing Loss Gene Curation Expert Panel on 11/21/2017 (SOP Version 5). It was reevaluated with the addition of one publication (PMID: 31656313) on 1/19/2022 (SOP v8). As a result of this reevaluation, the classification did not change.

evidence.dc:description: TMEM132E transcripts were present in mouse cochlea at a high level compared to other tissues by RT-qPCR. Protein levels, assessed by western blot as well as immunofluorescent staining, confirmed this result. TMEM132E localized to apical and basal region of OHC body in P30 mice, while OHC localization in P0 mice was more diffuse. Expression was also observed in spiral ganglion, stria vascularis, and IHCs of both ages of mice
evidence.rdfs:label: TMEM132E Is Highly Expressed in Hair Cells of Mouse Cochlea

evidence.dc:description: AG: After review, Zebrafish model was given a total of 3 points with the rescue.

Because the wild-type human TMEM132E mRNA could rescue the TMEM132E-knockdown phenotype in zebrafish, the function of human TMEM132E may be highly similar to that of zebrafish and could compensate for the loss of endogenous zebrafish TMEM132E.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of Knockout Phenotype with WT

evidence.dc:description: AG: After review, Zebrafish model was given a total of 3 points with the rescue.

Zebrafish were generated with TMEM132E antisense morpholino oligos designed to knock out exon 3.  MO-injected larvae showed a delayed startle response and circular swimming behavior, suggesting hearing loss. MO larvae showed significantly reduced extracellular receptor potentials relative to controls. Evidence that mechanoelectrical transduction is disrupted in TMEM132E knockout fishes compared to controls. Fluorescently labelled neuromasts were compared in MO and control fish, and there was a significant reduction in the number of neuromasts in the MO fish, suggesting reduced uptake of the fluorophore and thus impaired mechanoelectrical transduction. SEM revealed significant difference between MO-injected and control larvae in semilunar periderm cellular morphology. In severely affected larvae, hair bundles were absent.
evidence.rdfs:label: TMEM132E Is Required for Hair Cell Development in Zebra Fish
IV:3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Bilateral profound sensorineural HI. HI is prelingual and most likely congenital, since it was detected before the age of one in all affected family members. The hearing impaired family members were physically examined, neither gross vestibular dysfunction nor any episodes of vertigo were observed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Prior to exome sequencing, the entire coding region of GJB2, which is a common cause of HI, was screened by Sanger sequencing. Additional common ARHI variants in the Pakistani population were also screened via Sanger sequencing: i.e., intronic HGF variants (c.482+1986_1988delTGA and c.482+1991_2000delGATGATGAAA), missense variants p.(Phe91Ser), and p.(Cys99Trp) within CIB2 and SLC26A4 missense variants p.(Gln446Arg) and p.(Val239Asp)

evidence.dc:description: The Hearing Loss VCEP chose to score this genetic evidence for both variants at a total of 1.5 points. Each variant was scored at 0.5 points for in silico comparative modeling functional data and an additional 0.5 points were awarded for segregation data.
Three-dimensional protein modeling predicted that the A128S variant establishes a strong interaction network with nearby residues.
Three-dimensional protein modeling predicted that the P825L mutation leads to local conformational changes in nearby residues.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient IV-3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Prelingual, bilateral, severe to profound SNHL
evidence.previousTestingDescription: In a previous study, the ARNSHL locus was mapped to an interval of 5.07 cM on chromosome 17q12 by genome-wide homozygosity mapping [Cheng et al., 2003]; the locus was designated as DFNB99. However, the search for the causative gene had been hampered due to the large size of the critical region.

evidence.dc:description: AG: This score was changed from 1 point to 0.25 points during the call with the experts. The closest score in the GCI, 0.2 points, were awarded.
WT, but not p.Arg420Gln human TMEM132E could rescue TMEM132E knockout zebrafish
